Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Effects of nitrogen addition on ectomycorrhizal communities in tropical montane forest
Award.AbstractNarration:
Tropical forests are renowned for their high biodiversity, with hundreds or even thousands of tree species living together at a single site. In some tropical forests, however, a single tree species can outnumber all other species combined. Recent attempts to explain this one-species dominance have focused on the role of soil microbes in determining which tree species are common and which are rare. Attention has been on beneficial associations between trees and fungi in their roots, called mycorrhizas. A leading idea about why some tropical trees are so common is that they are uniquely capable of forming associations with particular types of mycorrhizal fungi that provide access to nitrogen that is unavailable to less common tree species. Experimental work from a forest in western Panama is consistent with this hypothesis, leading to the question of how this plant-mycorrhizal association, and therefore tree community composition, may be disrupted by increasing rates of nitrogen deposition from the atmosphere. Will this new and relatively plentiful form of nitrogen make mycorrhizal fungi unimportant? Effects of nitrogen on the plant-mycorrhizal association of a dominant tree will be addressed by comparing mycorrhizal fungal communities in forest plots with and without a treatment of nitrogen fertilization over the last eight years. This project will also provide training in fungal genetics and ecology to a graduate student, and research mentoring for undergraduate students.

The ectomycorrhizal fungal community associated with a dominant canopy tree, Oreomunnea mexicana, will be characterized in eight forest plots located in lower montane forest at Fortuna, Panama. Four of the plots have received a nitrogen addition treatment four times per year since 2008. In each plot, root samples will be collected from Oreomunnea trees and ectomycorrhizal communities characterized using Illumina sequencing. It is predicted that nitrogen addition will reduce the diversity and infection frequency of ectomycorrhizal taxa and result in a shift in the composition and phylogenetic structure of ectomycorrhizal communities, favoring lineages known to contain nitrophilic taxa.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Microbes (bacteria and fungi) found in the soil are increasingly recognized as an important factor influencing plant abundance in tropical forests. Traditionally, two mechanisms have been identified that link the success of individual plant species to microbes. Pathogenic microbes could limit the abundance of plant species because disease can spread more easily from one host plant to another when plants occur at high density. Or, alternatively, beneficial microbes (fungi) might facilitate the maintenance of high densities of a particular plant species by connecting them together via a shared network of fungal tissue. This tissue (called a hyphal network) could transfer scarce nutrients from one plant to another. The PhD thesis supported by this grant investigated another, previously unexplored possibility: plants with a particular fungal association in their roots called ectomycorrhizas (EM) are able to reduce the availability of nitrogen, a critical limiting nutrient in the soil, to competing plants that lack this association. This reduction in nitrogen availability provides a competitive advantage allowing EM-associated trees to achieve high abundance.

 

To explore aspects of the proposed link between EM fungi and nitrogen availability, this grant supported the analysis of the composition of EM fungal species that infect the roots of EM-associated trees in a tropical forest in Panama. The study took advantage of a long-running experiment, where addition of nitrogen fertilizer to the forest over a seven year period was predicted to reduce the competitive advantage held by EM-associated trees, and potentially alter which EM fungal species were present. The study found that nitrogen addition reduced the degree to which roots of EM-associated trees were infected by EM fungi. Furthermore, the composition of EM fungi was also altered, favoring some groups of fungal species over others in ways consistent with previous fertilization studies in temperate and boreal forests.

 

The industrialization and intensification of agriculture in tropical countries is resulting in increasing atmospheric deposition of nitrogen to tropical forests. The results obtained from this study suggest that increased nitrogen availability has the potential to disrupt the competitive balance between plant species groups favoring species that lack EM associations. This is of particular significance as EM-associated trees, such as oak and hickories, are dominant components of temperate forests, and of many tropical mountain forests. Furthermore, forests composed of EM-associated trees have been shown to store much larger amounts of carbon in the soil than those lacking EM-associated trees. Increasing nitrogen deposition could therefore have important consequences for the carbon cycle regionally and globally.
